raw_text:
Dallaglio eyeing Lions tour place
 
 Former England captain Lawrence Dallaglio still harbours hopes of a place on the British and Irish Lions tour to New Zealand.
 
 Lions coach Sir Clive Woodward has made it clear he will pick his squad to tour next summer based on form shown in the Six Nations championship. But Dallaglio, who called time on England earlier this year, said: "I assure you I wouldn't let anyone down. "I know what it takes and what I have to offer," he told the Daily Telegraph. Dallaglio toured South Africa with the Lions in 1997 but was forced home early with a knee injury from the trip to Australia three years ago.
 
 The 32-year-old also felt concentrating on club rugby could have prolonged his international shelf-life. He said: "I'll be in good shape and fresh without another 10 Tests on the clock. "From what I witnessed at close quarters on Sunday in our Heineken Cup match against Leicester, I certainly didn't feel out of place alongside those players, many of whom will be on the trip.
 
 "If I'm fit and playing well, then I'm most certainly available. "If Clive feels he has no need to look outside the international crop, then fine. If he does, then he won't need to look too far, will he?"
llama3.2:1b: Lawrence Dallaglio hopes to tour with the British and Irish Lions next summer, despite being 32 and feeling out of place in a team that may be selecting from younger players.
He has toured South Africa and Australia previously but was forced home due to injury three years ago.
llama3.2:3b: Lawrence Dallaglio wants a place on the British and Irish Lions tour to New Zealand despite not playing in the Six Nations championship.
He believes he can offer value if picked based on his experience and fitness.

He acknowledges that Sir Clive Woodward will select players based on their recent performance and has expressed confidence in his ability to contribute if chosen.
Dallaglio's past experience on a Lions tour, as well as concerns about adding more international matches to his workload, led him to prioritize club rugby over prolonged international service.

Dallaglio played for the Lions in 1997 and was forced home from Australia in 2004 due to injury.

He told the Daily Telegraph: "I assure you I wouldn't let anyone down.
I know what it takes and what I have to offer."
Dallaglio has taken part in South Africa with the Lions since he left Australia three years ago, but was forced home due to a knee injury.
The 32-year-old is also concerned about club rugby, as he felt he could concentrate on this without having to wait for another 10 Tests.
He said: "I'll be in good shape and fresh without another 10 Tests on the clock."
Despite what he has experienced at close quarters, Dallaglio's players were not out of place.
smollm:1.7b: Dallaglio would not let anyone down if he were to tour next summer with the British and Irish Lions.
He knows what it takes and what he has to offer, and he is confident that he can continue to play at a high level.
From his experience playing for the Lions in 1997, Dallaglio knew that he would need to be in good shape and fresh without another 10 Tests on the clock if he were to compete internationally.
He also felt that concentrating on club rugby could have prolonged his international shelf-life as it was during his time playing for the Lions.
From what I witnessed at close quarters on Sunday in our Heineken Cup match against Leicester, Dallaglio did not feel out of place alongside those players who would be on the trip to New Zealand.
In fact, he felt that he was most certainly available and ready to play his part if he were to tour next summer with the Lions.
If Clive feels he has no need to look outside the international crop, then he won't need to look too far, will he?
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Lawrence Dallaglio hopes to join the British and Irish Lions tour to New Zealand after performing well in the Six Nations championship.

Sir Clive Woodward plans to select his squad for the upcoming summer tour based on their form from the championship, but Dallaglio remains confident, stating, "I assure you I wouldn't let anyone down."
Dallaglio, who has concluded his England career, expressed pride in his team's success and emphasized that he won't allow anyone to down him.
He highlighted his experience with South Africa before international duty but stressed the need for more international exposure.
Dallaglio believes being fit and fresh will make him available, while he also notes if the coach is willing to look abroad, it may not be necessary.

However, former England captain Lawrence Dallaglio still hopes to make the cut.
The former skipper expressed a desire to show his worth and play an integral role, even if he is not called upon.
He believed that concentrating on club rugby could have prolonged his international career, citing his experience at the Heiniken Cup match against Leicester.
If Sir Clived opts to leave out Dallaglio, there will be no need for further speculation or explanation, as he has every reason to believe he will get a call.

Despite being retired from England earlier this year, Dallaglio asserts his readiness for the tour, emphasizing his current fitness and ability to perform at a high level in club rugby.
He points out that he didn't seem out of place during a recent match against Leicester, suggesting he could still compete with potential Lions players.
